questions.question_text: Using an ROT13 cipher to protect confidential information for unauthorized access is known as:

comments.content: Confirmed. Obfuscation is the correct answer.

discussion.content:
B is right, ROT13 is for hidden/obfuscation messages.
A steganography is hidden message within a picture/photo.

Obfuscation (XOR, ROT13, Substitution ciphers)

Because ROT13 uses both the same algorithm and the same key, it doesn’t provide true encryption but instead just obfuscates the data.

Gibson, Darril. CompTIA Security+ Get Certified Get Ahead: SY0-501 Study Guide (p. 436). Kindle Edition.

comments.content:
because ROT13 uses both the same algorithm and the same key, it doesn’t provide true encryption but instead just obfuscates the data.
From Gibson's book.

discussion.content:
correct answer A
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ROT13

questions.question_text: A company is implementing a tool to mask all PII when moving data from a production server to a testing server. Which of the following security techniques is the company applying?

discussion.content:
based on what I understand in this link, the provided answer is correct.
https://www.imperva.com/learn/data-security/data-obfuscation/
the answer C is correct , Steganography hides inside a photo while data sanitisation, clean and destroy all data

comments.content: its wrong the correct answer is Data Obfuscation
You are right because obfuscation is not the answer insteady Steganography used to conceal software programs especially in the testing center not on production server

discussion.content: The answer should be B. It said mask=hide. Steganography hides data

Answer should be D

Keyword: Mask
Data sanitisation = data mask

comments.content: wrong data sanitization involves removing residual data from a device in order to avoid traces of data being rediscovered after a data wipe process while obfuscation is the act of masking data. please stop misleading others

questions.question_text:
A security analyst has received several reports of an issue on an internal web application. Users state they are having to provide their credentials twice to log in.
The analyst checks with the application team and notes this is not an expected behavior. After looking at several logs, the analyst decides to run some commands on the gateway and obtains the following output:
//IMG//

Which of the following BEST describes the attack the company is experiencing?

discussion.content: C is right. if you think about it, they are all dynamic and static just poisoned the log. This is very right
If you see where the last MAC says static, this MAC is forged and its indication of ARP poisoning.
Is this correct and if so why? I really struggled with logout puts.

comments.content:
...While static entries provide some security against spoofing, they result in maintenance efforts as address mappings for all systems in the network must be generated and distributed.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARP_spoofing#Static_ARP_entries

questions.question_text: A technician needs to document which application versions are listening on open ports. Which of the following is MOST likely to return the information the technician needs?

discussion.content: Open ports=Banner grabbing
Helloworld is correct.
comptia shows no less love to banner grabbing than faraday cage.

anner Grabbing is a technique used to gain information about a computer system on a network and the services running on its open ports.

A protocol analyzer is a tool (hardware or software) used to capture and analyze signals and data traffic over a communication channe

comments.content:
"Banner Grabbing is a technique used to gain information about a computer system on a network and the services running on its open ports"

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banner_grabbing

Per Wikipedia, Banner Grabbing is a technique used to gain information about a computer system on a network and the services running on its open ports. Administrators can use this to take inventory of the systems and services on their network.

discussion.content: Why is this banner grabbing and not protocol analyzer

questions.question_text: A government contracting company issues smartphones to employees to enable access to corporate resources. Several employees will need to travel to a foreign country for business purposes and will require access to their phones. However, the company recently received intelligence that its intellectual property is highly desired by the same country's government. Which of the following MDM configurations would BEST reduce the disk of compromise while on foreign soil?

comments.content: I'm going with A but honestly it could go both ways. This feels like another tossup question

Also going with A.
In this case, the updates can cause a problem when abroad.

Well unfortunately Messer doesn't write the comptia exam questions. Disabling OTA, Location, and Push Notifications are all good answer depending on the capabilities of the adversary. Stupid question with ambigious answers that depends.

discussion.content:
I believe A is correct

From Messer videos Mobile Device Enforcement 2.5: (Talking about OTA updates) "This may or may not be a good thing. There could be a patch release that could change the way a particular application operates on that mobile device and it could prevent you to be able to do the work that is required from your organization."
As I understand it, an OTA update could result in an application vulnerability and that could lead to a nation state exploiting it. I think this is a bigger threat than the provided answer of disabling location services. Meanwhile geolocation can track someone within a few feet, this solution implies theft of the device which could be the more immediate concern. However a remote wipe would have to be implemented which may not work considering you are rivaling a nation-state aka they have unlimited resources which means they probably would know to turn off the device or wrap it in a faraday cage or another method to prevent this which means the window for remote wipe is small. I think it would be smarter for them to exploit a vulnerability from a poor ota update without raising any eyebrows
I think there is a typo in the question. It should be "risk of compromise" not "disk of compromise". I guess that is the only way the disabling location services lowers the risk.

The primary concern surrounding location services is one of privacy. Although very useful when used with navigation systems, it provides a mechanism to track an individual's movements, and therefore their social habits. The problem is further compounded by the plethora of mobile apps that require access to location services and then both send the information to the application developers and store it within the device's file structure. If an attacker can gain access to this data, then stalking, social engineering, and even identity theft become real possibilities.
Let’s go A
A is the correct answer
i believe A ... i thought this was a repeat question too.

comments.content: Some updates can be bad. This is why we have a whole patch management system so certain updates won't take an entire company down!

discussion.content:
While on Foreign soil?? B is the only logical answer for me. You don't want adversaries tracking your moves as a foreign national. 

Option A I doesn't make sense because you would ESPECIALLY need the latest updates to stay as protected from potential vulnerabilities and attacks as possible. You can get the latest security updates while having adversaries incapable of tracking you.

I believe the answer is B is because they are implying that since they are on foreign land, they need to turn of their location services to make it harder for someone to track them and possibly seal their device.

comments.content: First one makes more sense in terms of security but because we are playing comptia game, answer will be location for me.

discussion.content:
Read this option A sounds a lot better than B:

https://searchmobilecomputing.techtarget.com/definition/OTA-update-over-the-air-update

 OEMs that don't properly secure their OTA update process can enable hackers to change the device's software. Attackers can push unofficial updates that introduce security vulnerabilities. For example, an OTA company called Adups, based in China, installed adware and spyware to collect personal information from devices.

To avoid security breaches, OEMs should encrypt and authenticate OTA updates and deliver them to end users via a secure protocol.
How does disabling location provide reduce the risk of compromise on foreign soil? Are we supposed to assume the device is being tracked by Putin?

Not sure how disabling location services is going to help prevent or mitigate the threat. Is the bad actor's trying to steal the device and by disabling location-based service we are trying to hide the device's location or prevent tracking? Not sure if that could be considered the BEST Option.
My vote would be for A. Disable firmware OTA Update. It's not a very good answer - however from the list of answer's I prefer that the most. Scanning security patches and updates to make sure it does not impact any of the existing applications or disrupt any essential service is a common practice. Also with state-sponsored actors probably they could aim for a firmware hack? With that in mind I believe disabling OTA update and pushing update through an MDM or some other channel could be considered appropriate for this highly-sensitive device. Hence, my preference to A.
